body: This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/c-toxcore/2454)

comment_data.body: Simply checked the CI logs during one of my recent PRs. Apparently `clang --analyze` has been complaining about this for a while now without anyone noticing. I have then ran clang locally, generating HTML reports to see the full code traces and confirm the memory leaks for myself, as static analyzers sometimes find false positives -- and it did indeed fine some true positives.
Are there analyses we should mark as errors so we don't miss them in the future?

They do report false positives sometimes, even the same memory leak type of warning that helped find these -- `unix.Malloc` -- currently reports `./toxcore/list.c:247:5: warning: Use of memory after it is freed [unix.Malloc]` which looks like a false positive to me, so I'm not sure about having them error.

It would be nice if we could somehow make it so that newly found warnings, ones that are absent in the branch we are merging the PR into but are present in the PR branch, would require signing off before a PR can be merged, individually every warning one by one, and it would be even nicer if the HTML code traces generated by the static analyses tools could be viewed right from the PR without having to run the tool locally yourself -- but those are very big asks.

I wonder if treating all warnings as errors and having the PR author rewrite their code such that the static analysis tool doesn't trip over it, even if it's a false positive, is a good idea? Not sure.

performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.®

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ
- Do you **merge multiple uploads** to the same commit? **Yes**
- Do you **support multiple languages** in the same project? **Yes**
- Can you **group coverage reports** by project and/or test type? **Yes**
- How does **pricing** work? Only paid users can view reports and post statuses/comments.
